Problem:
Consider a control system where the dynamic behavior is governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Mx + Nu\\), with \\(M\\) and \\(N\\) as constant matrices and \\(u\\) the control input. We test the impact of applying a linear transformation \\(T(v) = P v\\) where \\(P\\) is another constant matrix, on the control input \\(u(t)\\) over time \\(t\\).

If an additional transformation \\(S(v) = Qv\\) is applied at a specific time \\(t_1 > 0\\) to the control input, will the final state of the system \\(x(T)\\) solely depend on the applied transformations \\(T\\) and \\(S\\), independent of the matrix dimensions and properties?
Explanation: The final state \\(x(T)\\) will depend on a complex interplay between the matrices \\(M\\), \\(N\\), \\(P\\) and \\(Q\\) due to continuous dynamic influence throughout the time interval. The properties and dimensions of these matrices will dictate how transformations interact and influence the system's trajectory.
